pbr/util.py.message: Oh, yep, this goes back to why the original change was incorrect. We shouldn't have implemented this with the alias target as the "key" but should have used the alias itself and reversed the order. But the refactor to get there would be a bit more significant i suppose.

The line before this will have created an entry already, which this will then replace, making these at the very least order-dependent, right? Rather, shouldn't the first one be removed and replaced by the new entry?

I read through the code that loops through this list and I believe this is mostly correct. Basically what it does is for every entry in this list it checks the ini setup.cfg for the data and handles it properly if found.

For ('python_requires', ('metadata',)) it will look for:

  [metadata]
  python_requires = stuff

In the setup.cfg file and pass it along properly.

For ('python_requires', ('metadata', 'requires_python')) it will look for:

  [metadata]
  requires_python = stuff

In the setup.cfg file, rewrite the requires_python content to python_requires and then use that value for setup.py.

This means that if you have both requires_python and python_requires in setup.cfg then requires_python will win. I guess we might prefer python_requires to win but one of them does need to win.

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_ni.message: As far as I can tell, the bug is caused by using the snap_id in last_snap from the volume instead of making a call out to the API to get the snap_id.  Since the value of 'id' here is the same as snap_id on line 168, there's no way to tell if you're getting the id from the volume info or from making the API call.  If you make this fake.SNAPSHOT_ID_2 or something, then you can change the expected calls at line 1293 to have fake.SNAPSHOT_ID_2 as the value of base_snap_id, and then you'll know the code is getting the value from the API call.   Or you can do something completely different--the key thing is that you should have a test that can detect the bug you're fixing.

doc/source/admin/policy-yaml-file.rst.message:
I think this is a bit confusing. I see that Nova is populating the target object with project_id in some cases, but since that is also an API attribute it's awkward to use it as an example for the target attributes too.

What I had in mind is more something like this possible glance policy: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742810/3/doc/source/admin/interoperable-image-import.rst

In that case, 'visibility' is a key in the target that deployers can use in their custom policy. The question I want to answer in the documentation is how to find out all of the keys available in the target object, which requires looking at the debug log output because it's an arbitrary dict passed in by the service.

The other thing that we need to document (but doesn't necessarily need to be done in this change) is how to enable debug logging of oslo.policy. It isn't as simple as turning on debug in the service because oslo.policy is one of the overridden defaults in https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log/src/branch/master/oslo_log/_options.py#L30 That means you also have to override https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log/src/branch/master/oslo_log/_options.py#L175 in order to get debug output from oslo.policy.

I agree with this. For deployers, it is not an easy way to determine that with what all value they can customize the policy until they deep dive into the code. One example is this: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/751152/1/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py

I think we need some tools that can convert the passed target from service into the docstring per policy. If policy help or description can tell what all value for this policy is available to customize then it will solve the problem.

Technically - this information could be generalized outside of the yaml-specific documentation here.

It seems relevant to the documentation we publish in the API reference [0].

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy/src/branch/master/oslo_policy/policy.py#L30

oslo_versionedobjects/base.py.message:
I might add that fields without value provided at __init__ and without default value will be left uninitialized by this mixing.

As an alternative behavior for these fields would be that the __init__ raises if such field exists to avoid non initialized fields after __init__.

Given how the fields-can-be-unset behavior is baked so deeply into VersionedObject, I think that would be pretty jarring. It would also make it hard to have an object without a field set if you needed it, and would probably result in people making everything nullable=True,default=None which is worse, IMHO.

+ 
23:10 < dansmith> all our objects used to be basically 1:1 mappings for the db, but over time we've grown a lot more of these general purpose ones, so it used to be easy to say "you can never ever do this"


I did not fully aware the original design intention behind ovo. So thanks for clarifying it.
As far as I understand an ovo that represents a db row never really want to have defaulted ovo field as such defaulting should happen in the db schema level instead. Is it valid understanding?
ah, thanks for the defining the set semantic.
For create, yes. For update, there's no defaulting because having a field unset in the object means "leave this column set to whatever it currently is."
yeah this is the use case where I would need defaulting during __init__

+2, I want this.

Alternatively I would be OK to have the defaulting happen at lazy load time if it is also done automatically. But the current proposal is the less complex, more understandable one.
Yeah, there's no real reason to do it at lazy-load time if we have this categorical classification of objects that behave this way.

"completely agree and that's something that has bugged me, but it seemed like the design from the start of this change was to separate device-backed OSD targeting from directory-backed ones.  Fixing this is straightforward, but not entirely trivial.  Given we _really_ need this merged asap, my personal preference is to eliminate the distinction in a later change."
this looks odd, why would you want to set this value?

the crushmap is based on hostnames.  In a world where you've got multiple OSD containers on a single host, you typically want to be certain they all get the same hostname so that the assumptions about failure domains are maintained.  This allows you to control that.

However, I think it's probably not necessarily best to have it set on a per-block-device basis, so this could probably go away.

ceph/values.yaml.message: Since I would be deploying a single chart, responsible for ceph across many hosts, how would I be articulating to use these 4 disks in this host, and these 6 disks on this other host with this approach?
I think we need to recommend using persistent device path such as /dev/disk/by-uuid/<uuid>

Yeah, trying to pick an ID which was unlikely to change across reboots was the point of using SCSI IDs as for attached disks they're unlikely to change.  This point is well-taken though.  I'll add comments that stress the importance of picking stable device names.  Since as you observe, we already resolve symlinks at the top of osd_disk_{prepare,activate}, we should be OK if users configure this with a link.

> I think we need to recommend using persistent device path such as
 > /dev/disk/by-uuid/<uuid>

Agree with this, SCSI IDs may change on a reboot. We've worked around this by passing in "/dev/disk/by-id/wwn-id" and then adding OSD_DEVICE=$(readlink -f ${OSD_DEVICE}) to _osd_disk_activate.sh.tpl, which is a total hack but works for our use case. :)

this should use the snippet from here: http://logs.openstack.org/54/457754/69/check/gate-openstack-helm-multi-basic-linuxbridge-rbd-ubuntu-xenial-3-node-nv/e087028/console.html#_2017-10-10_18_37_19_108743

this snippet will need to be modified to match the format you propose, but it is essential that the OSD deployment is aware of hosts - and able to target potentially differing disc topology across them.

The format is correct, as we have discussed on slack I think this format is better than the initial one I produced - but this should be generated dynamically and not hardcoded into the ceph chart. Your point RE host label targetting is fair - but we need to be able to feed these charts yaml document that represents the disc topology for a whole site - which may include several other services (eg Swift, Cinder LVM etc), this presents choice, either target by hostname as well - or simply ignore that level in the yaml.

Unless I'm missing something, this _is_ the correct format.  The idea is that what goes in values.yaml is not host-specific.  Instead, OSD host targeting happens using labels.   The way the differences in host hardware is expressed is by assigning them different labels corresponding to the name: values in this map.  So, if host1 has a disk at 2:0:0.1 and host2 at 2:0.0.2, host1 would get the label  cephosd-device-scsi-2-0-0-1 and host2 cephosd-device-scsi-2-0-0-2.  Values.yaml, then, contains the union of ALL potential disk presences.

postgresql/templates/bin/_postgres.sh.tp.message:
what if we already have one of

# log_statement ...
log_statement ...
Yes, the change is part of configuration file  and is being applied while container start up and the configuration is set with sed command.

The sed command is to just to enable the debug log by replacing #log_statement with log_statement=All.
If there is an already entry of  log_statement, it means there is already log enabled and sed command won't run.
Why is this being handled via sed?  Is setting a value in the configuration file not sufficient?
You have changed nothing in the chart that would cause this file to ever be run.

"sed" is not a good option for the long-term maintenance of the chart. It's fragile (may stop working if the upstream config file changes in the postgreql image) and hard to interpret for someone reading the chart. Instead, you should do one of two things:
1. Create a template for the whole file, or
2. update _start.sh.tpl with these options as command-line arguments. For example, postgres --help shows you that you can specify debugging level:
  -d 1-5             debugging level

This is a separate thing from setting the log level. Setting log_statement to 'all' will cause all SQL transactions to be logged, potentially creating high disk space and I/O utilization. You can expose this logging option as well, but you can't have it be the default.

"log_min_error_statement" is a separate parameter (the one you want originally) that can be set to "INFO", "ERROR", etc. Please read https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.5/runtime-config-logging.html

postgresql/values.yaml.message: This should default to INFO, at least. DEBUG isn't a very sane default option here
What's the point of this if you never reference the variable set here?

Have you validated actually works? The documentation for "-d" says:
-d 1-5             debugging level
So I would not expect "INFO" to work since the documentation says it expects a number from 1 to 5. Please investigate this postgres option and test it to ensure it works as you expect.
Is there any specific reason you have added the log_min_messages under logging section?
can it be replaced by a verbose string mapped to the integer?
replacing with verbose string is not possible as in postgres -d option takes values as integer.

deliverables/wallaby/python-tripleoclien.message:
I think that it should be a major version (16.0.0).

Two command have been removed:

- openstack overcloud parameters set
- openstack overcloud plan

hey Herve, so we already bumped the major to 15.0.0 for the first wallaby release in Jan.

In tripleo we bump the major for each new release (apart from the times that we broke this pattern, like Ussuri which you may recall).

So 14 was victoria series, 15 will be wallaby series.

This is why I bumped to 15.1.0 - does it make sense?

https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/tags

Well, during Victoria we did more or less opposite :) 

Let's wait a bit for other opinions. Concerning myself I would argue that a major version is required

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/releases/+/759449

From a semantic versioning point of view it should be a major version.

From the deliverable type point of view, we don't have specific rules from a serie to another for this kind of deliverable, so, I think that nothing prevents us to release a major version at this point, and nothing prevents you to start Xena with a major version too (17.0.0).

I think that our priority is to provide an understandable semantic to customers/users. A major version will inform them that breaking changes are landed.

Thoughts?

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/release-management.html#choosing-a-release-model

>  From a semantic versioning point of view it should be a major version.

no arguments on that point from me, agree ^^


As I said the reason was because we always bump a major for new stable/branch releases. Because we made a wallaby 'release' already for the deadline a while back, we bumped it at that point to 15 for wallaby and I wanted to continue in this series.

Now we don't _have_ to use 15... the wallaby series can be 16, it is still a major bump.
It just breaks the usual pattern - i.e. If someone checks that victoria is 14 they might expect 15 to be wallaby but actually it will be 16. Of course you would have to be familiar with what we usually do in tripleo for it to be confusing so perhaps that list of people is very small ;) and it doesn't matter if it is confusing
